slides.title: Niels Bohr
slides.caption: Danish physicist Niels Bohr announced the discovery of atomic fission at a conference in Washington, D.C., in 1939. He subsequently joined thousands of other scientists and intellectuals who migrated to Great Britain and the United States at the outbreak of World War II. Bohr then played a central role in the development of the first atomic weapons at Los Alamos.

slides.title: Edward Teller
slides.caption: Hungarian physicist Edward Teller urged Albert Einstein to alert U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt to the threat posed by Nazi scientists' work on nuclear technology. Following his work on the Manhattan Project, Teller helped to develop the more powerful hydrogen bomb in the 1950s.
slides.source: Courtesy of Los Alamos National Laboratory

slides.title: Albert Einstein
slides.caption: This photograph of the world-renowned scientist Albert Einstein was taken at a lecture he gave in Vienna in 1921.

slides.title: Enrico Fermi
slides.caption: This photograph of Italian physicist Enrico Fermi was taken in 1950 following his work with the Manhattan Project in Los Alamos. He naturalized as a U.S. citizen in 1944 and he held a post in the Physics Department at the University of Chicago until his death in 1954.
